title: The Midnight Library
author: Matt Haig
description:
In a library between life and death, Nora Seed finds herself with the chance to rewrite her story. Each book on the shelves offers a glimpse into a different path—what could have been if she had made different choices.

As she explores these alternate realities, Nora begins to uncover the things that truly matter. 'The Midnight Library' is a poignant and imaginative novel that explores regret, possibility, and the courage it takes to live.

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
description:
Forming good habits doesn't have to be a struggle. In 'Atomic Habits', James Clear breaks down the science behind how habits are formed and shows readers simple, actionable steps to build lasting routines.

Packed with insights from psychology, neuroscience, and real-world examples, this book offers a proven framework for transformation. Whether you're looking to improve your career, health, or relationships, Clear’s strategies make it attainable.

title: The Alchemist
author: Paulo Coelho
description:
Santiago, a young Andalusian shepherd, dreams of a treasure hidden in the Egyptian pyramids. He sets out on a quest that takes him across continents in pursuit of a dream that keeps calling to him.

But the journey becomes more than just a physical adventure—it becomes a journey of self-discovery. 'The Alchemist' is a timeless tale about listening to your heart and embracing the path of your personal legend.

title: Where the Crawdads Sing
author: Delia Owens
description:
In the marshes of North Carolina, Kya Clark grows up isolated from the townspeople who call her 'Marsh Girl.' When a local man is found dead, suspicions quickly turn to her.

The novel weaves together a gripping murder mystery with a touching coming-of-age story. It's also a love letter to the wild beauty of nature and the resilience of those who live on its margins.

title: Becoming
author: Michelle Obama
description:
From her childhood on the South Side of Chicago to her years as First Lady of the United States, Michelle Obama recounts her extraordinary journey with grace and honesty.

In 'Becoming', she shares personal reflections on her role as a mother, a leader, and a public figure navigating uncharted waters. It’s an inspiring memoir that encourages readers to find their voice and own their story.

title: Educated
author: Tara Westover
description:
Raised in a strict and isolated household in rural Idaho, Tara Westover never stepped foot in a classroom until the age of seventeen. Her thirst for knowledge led her on a remarkable journey—from self-taught learner to earning a PhD from Cambridge.

'Educated' is a memoir about the struggle for self-invention, the clash between loyalty to family and loyalty to oneself, and the power of education to transform a life.

title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck
author: Mark Manson
description:
Mark Manson delivers a raw, refreshing perspective on how to live a better life—not by avoiding problems, but by learning how to deal with them better. His no-nonsense advice is built on the idea that life’s struggles give it meaning.

Blending humor, personal stories, and psychological research, this book offers readers permission to care less about unimportant things and more about what really matters. It’s a guide to developing resilience and clarity in an increasingly chaotic world.

title: Daisy Jones & The Six
author: Taylor Jenkins Reid
description:
Told in an oral-history format, 'Daisy Jones & The Six' captures the rise and fall of a fictional 1970s rock band. Through interviews with band members and those around them, the novel paints a vivid picture of fame, creativity, and heartbreak.

As secrets unravel and egos collide, the story dives deep into the tensions that drove the band to greatness—and ultimately to break apart. It's a gripping and immersive narrative filled with passion, music, and nostalgia.

title: Free Food For Millionaires
author: Min Jin Lee
description:
Casey Han, a Princeton graduate from a Korean immigrant family, finds herself torn between two cultures and struggling to forge a life of her own. Ambitious and intelligent, Casey craves wealth and independence but often finds herself at odds with society’s expectations.

This richly layered novel explores identity, ambition, class, and the sacrifices made for belonging. It’s a sweeping story of family, privilege, and the pursuit of self-worth in modern America.

title: It Ends With Us
author: Colleen Hoover
description:
Lily Bloom appears to have it all: a new city, a blossoming career, and a charming love interest. But when the darkness of her past begins to echo in her present relationship, she is forced to confront difficult truths.

'It Ends With Us' is a powerful and emotional story about love, strength, and the decisions that define us. Hoover tackles tough themes like abuse and trauma with honesty and sensitivity, delivering a story that resonates deeply with readers.

author: George Orwell
description:
In a chilling dystopia ruled by Big Brother, individual freedom is crushed beneath the weight of totalitarian control. Winston Smith, a low-ranking Party member, dares to question the regime, seeking truth in a world built on lies.

'1984' is a timeless warning about surveillance, censorship, and the manipulation of truth. Orwell's masterpiece remains disturbingly relevant, challenging readers to reflect on power, control, and resistance.

title: The Silent Parade
author: Keigo Higashino
description:
When a beloved young woman is found murdered, suspicion falls on a man who had previously escaped justice. Years later, as tensions rise in the neighborhood, the case resurfaces with shocking consequences.

Blending psychological depth with procedural intrigue, 'The Silent Parade' is a gripping mystery that challenges assumptions and keeps readers guessing until the final page. Keigo Higashino once again proves his mastery of the suspense genre.

title: The Original Daughter
author: Jemimah Wei
description:
In this compelling blend of myth and memory, 'The Original Daughter' explores the spiritual and emotional complexities of identity. Rooted in cultural heritage and personal mythology, the narrative challenges conventions and embraces transformation.

Jemimah Wei crafts a story that is at once deeply personal and universally resonant. Through lyrical prose and introspective depth, the novel becomes a meditation on family, truth, and spiritual awakening.

title: Careless People
author: Sarah Wynn-Williams
description:
Set in Nazi Germany, 'Careless People' follows a young girl who finds refuge from the horrors around her by stealing books. Through her love of words and stories, she discovers hope, humanity, and the courage to resist.

With poetic grace and emotional force, Sarah Wynn-Williams crafts a tale that is as heartbreaking as it is inspiring. It’s a reminder of the enduring power of literature in the darkest of times.

title: Fundamentally
author: Nussaibah Younis
description:
When a catastrophic event threatens Earth, a lone astronaut must undertake a perilous mission that could determine the fate of humanity. But survival in space is only part of the challenge—what awaits back home is just as daunting.

'Fundamentally' is a thrilling science fiction novel that blends action with philosophical reflection. It explores themes of isolation, sacrifice, and the fundamental questions that drive human progress.

title: Growth
author: Daniel Susskind
description:
In a world increasingly shaped by innovation and automation, how do we continue to grow—economically, socially, and intellectually? 'Growth' explores the modern dilemmas of advancement and the costs that often come with it.

Susskind challenges readers to rethink traditional notions of progress, urging us to consider not just what we grow, but how and why. It’s a thought-provoking read for anyone interested in the future of humanity and the planet.
